physical_appearance:This is a scarf of Force 136. It has a white base
 with fraying ends. Embroidered on the scarf is a portrait image of a man in a collared uniform in blue. There are initials on the bottom-right of the man\u0027s portrait. On the underside of the scarf
 there is a embroidered image of a coast
 with a name
 date and place embroidered underneath it. The scarf is slightly stained.

sgcool_label_text:This scarf belongs to Lung Chui Ying and forms part of a larger collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was amassed by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012)
 who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee
 which date from the mid-1990s to early 2000s. \r\n\r\nForce 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.\r\n\r\nLung Chui Ying was a Hainanese born in Johor and recruited as a Force 136 member to fight against the Japanese in Malaya.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a scarf of Force 136. It has a white base, with fraying ends. Embroidered on the scarf is a portrait image of a man in a collared uniform in blue. There are initials on the bottom-right of the man's portrait. On the underside of the scarf, there is a embroidered image of a coast, with a name, date and place embroidered underneath it. The scarf is slightly stained.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This scarf belongs to Lung Chui Ying and forms part of a larger collection of artefacts related to the World War II underground resistance movement known as Force 136. The collection of materials was amassed by Tan Chong Tee (1916- 2012), who was a key member of this resistance group. The collection consists of original materials belonging to Tan and other members of Force 136 dating from the 1940s to new materials reproduced from memory by Tan Chong Tee, which date from the mid-1990s to early 2000s. 

Force 136 was set up in July 1942 as part of the British Special Operations Executive (SOE). It recruited and trained local guerillas to gather intelligence and create an underground spy network to support planned British invasion of Japanese-occupied Malaya.

Lung Chui Ying was a Hainanese born in Johor and recruited as a Force 136 member to fight against the Japanese in Malaya.
